I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there is no valid reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are so many factors to consider that it cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin - heads can never be tails, but they are essentially the same. There are various civil rights associated with this, such as property taxes and healthcare, where a partner cannot be present if you are sick, as they are not technically considered family. I think this is absurd if you are spending the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar rates of success and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. What many people seem to get hung up on is that homosexuals are not asking for the right to get married in a church, but rather a legal marriage certificate provided by the government. If there is no involvement with church and state, this shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why people like Catholics would object to this on religious grounds, as it is a legal matter. If you are allowing someone a civil union, why not also allow them a legal marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. I think the federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should reflect this. However, I think President Bush has strong views on this matter, and his stance on gay marriage aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard against it are moral, but morality differs from person to person. To embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest is unethical. It's hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage while considering recent controversies such as the pledge of allegiance. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but this is not a valid reason. The American Psychological Association has stated that this is untrue. Institutions that actually do research should be listened to instead of popular opinion or religious beliefs.

First off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. You know, just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it has beneficial properties. So, I’d say no to making it available to the public. Absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I’d say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it’s beneficial; it’s not beneficial. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are a bunch of drugs that are illegal but pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Perocets, that kind of thing. And those are controlled substances. But we use them all the time because they’re beneficial. And if you deny that, just because there’s a taboo around marijuana, then there’s no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don’t think it’s that similar to alcohol because if you abuse marijuana, although if you abuse alcohol too, that can lead to bad things. It’s a tough one. I’d say you could integrate it, like let it become legal gradually but not all at once. Because then it would be abused, but if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it’s an illegal drug. But I mean, it’s not that bad for you. It’s not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. So, I mean, if we get rid of that image of marijuana as being this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly. And certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the twenty-first century. It's not as strict as it used to be. I remember growing up, I would always go to church every Sunday and wear cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there on the weekends. Now, as I've gotten older, they've started a teenager's mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during the summer. Families often come in late, so I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to get dressed up, people now wear jeans and khakis. I think the biggest change I've noticed is that the church I know doesn't involve me in its politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by changing policies like allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry. There are married men who become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. It's the individual, not the policies. I think that if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should consider a different faith. The sexuality of these priests might be based on genetics, not how they were brought up. I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening if they didn't know about it and were trying to cover it up. Shame on them if they did know and didn't act. As for other thoughts, I don't have any.

(laughs)

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still very much shaken by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq based on flimsy pretexts. Early on, the Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which turned out to be false.

That really rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war still upsets me. It seems to me that the Bush administration was very open about deceiving the American people and has yet to take responsibility. Even Colin Powell, who later admitted that he wasn’t convinced by the evidence when he presented it to the UN, called it a mistake.

That’s an impeachable offense, in my opinion. The Bush administration has shown complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to undermine it since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t remember the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made that allegation in his book after he was likely forced out of office, but it seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly due to his father’s administration. I think he also aimed to secure our energy supply, which is a very underhanded approach.

I think we should have pulled out a long time ago. Pulling out now could lead to a civil war, which would result in more deaths. The alternative proposed by the UN and the US, a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the best idea because it could also lead to long-term issues regarding Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, and the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister lacks control, and radical elements are vying for power.

I really don’t feel that it’s appropriate to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. I think it’s up to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. I feel that attempting to impose any kind of power over this issue would be against what has already been written in the constitution. I believe those trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in areas like Boston. I don’t think it’s the government’s place to decide what churches can and can’t make illegal. The separation of church and state is a key aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the United States. Even if an amendment were to be made, I think it would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don’t think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don’t see why he’s pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. I really feel it’s up to the churches, not the president or anyone in government, to decide this. There isn’t a good reason for an amendment banning it, as I don’t see how it would impact the economy or society positively.

Ok, the war in Iraq.

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which, in reality, had little to do with each other. The government exploited the public's outrage against the attacks to push for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I myself am strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes. The war in Iraq, in many ways, is reminiscent of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes, such as the high number of American soldiers who died. They removed Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath, including the power vacuum and chaos that ensued. The United States was attempting to install a democratic government, similar to their efforts in Vietnam. However, the government underestimated the difficulty and duration of the process.

I believe the government was not adequately prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We are still there, at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. The long process of training Iraqi troops and police forces is ongoing. The government may have tried to deceive the American people into believing it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. Implementing a new form of government takes years and is not an easy process, as seen in our own history.

The decision to go to war is difficult. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken away their government and way of life. However, we also need to consider the high risk and cost to American lives. Moreover, if the goal is to create a democratic nation, why just Iraq? The main reason is likely oil, as it's a significant source of our energy. The government's claims of Iraq having weapons of mass destruction turned out to be false, unlike in the case of North Korea, where we know they exist but have not attacked.

I hope that this war ends soon and that there will be peace, but I doubt that will happen.

I feel like the war has been prolonged for too long. Initially, the purpose was good, which was to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have lost sight of that purpose and are now fighting for the sake of proving our power. I think the original motivation had questionable aspects, such as George Bush's father's previous disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be justifiable, but if personal matters were involved, it would not be fair. I believe the war has been prolonged too much. Initially, starting the war was a clear statement, but it has dragged on for over a year now. If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I don't think our reason has remained consistent over time; it seems we are still at war just to be at war, and we don't want to leave without a decisive victory. I think the war has gone on long enough and should stop. There comes a point when the country's officials must fend for themselves. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions of dollars on this war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty. This war is a long-term drain on our economy. We should be spending that money on improving our own country, such as fixing roads and schools, and addressing healthcare issues. Right now, that money is being spent to kill our own citizens in a war we've lost the cause for. I think that's it.

My understanding is that they did not legalize it; they decriminalized it. This means it was reduced from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—something you might get cited for instead of being booked and arrested. When someone gets caught and cited for it, there are still potential ramifications, such as issues with job interviews and other formal situations, which are usually the worst effects of a drug charge. At least with a marijuana charge, people often worry about these long-term effects, even if it's decriminalized.

However, there's an argument that arresting and processing people can be expensive. It involves costs for booking, housing, court proceedings, and legal representation. Municipalities facing financial difficulties might not be willing to take on these additional expenses, even if it could free up funding for other public needs. In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it might be accepted. Here, the city might have more money to spend on education, social programs, and food assistance for the homeless due to the financial benefits.

I don't think everyone wants marijuana to be widely available and smoked everywhere, as it could be awkward and not socially accepted in many places. Additionally, it's hard to generalize about the effects of substances like marijuana and alcohol. They both have adverse effects on people, and individuals react differently based on their personal characteristics. Some people might use substances moderately, while others might not. Ultimately, both substances can have negative impacts, but how they affect each other can vary greatly from person to person.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there is no valid reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are so many factors to consider that it cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin - heads can never be tails, but they are essentially the same. There are various civil rights associated with this, such as property taxes and healthcare, where a partner cannot be present if you are sick, as they are not technically considered family. I think this is absurd if you are spending the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar rates of success and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. What many people seem to get hung up on is that homosexuals are not asking for the right to get married in a church, but rather a legal marriage certificate provided by the government. If there is no involvement with church and state, this shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why people like Catholics would object to this on religious grounds, as it is a legal matter. If you are allowing someone a civil union, why not also allow them a legal marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. I think the federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should reflect this. However, I think President Bush has strong views on this matter, and his stance on gay marriage aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard against it are moral, but morality differs from person to person. To embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest is unethical. It's hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage while considering recent controversies such as the pledge of allegiance. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but this is not a valid reason. The American Psychological Association has stated that this is untrue. Institutions that actually do research should be listened to instead of popular opinion or religious beliefs.

First off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. You know, just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it has beneficial properties. So, I’d say no to making it available to the public. Absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I’d say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it’s beneficial; it’s not beneficial. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are a bunch of drugs that are illegal but pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Perocets, that kind of thing. And those are controlled substances. But we use them all the time because they’re beneficial. And if you deny that, just because there’s a taboo around marijuana, then there’s no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don’t think it’s that similar to alcohol because if you abuse marijuana, although if you abuse alcohol too, that can lead to bad things. It’s a tough one. I’d say you could integrate it, like let it become legal gradually but not all at once. Because then it would be abused, but if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it’s an illegal drug. But I mean, it’s not that bad for you. It’s not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. So, I mean, if we get rid of that image of marijuana as being this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly. And certainly for medical purposes.

Nope.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the twenty-first century. It's not as strict as it used to be. I remember growing up, I would always go to church every Sunday and wear cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there on the weekends. Now, as I've gotten older, they've started a teenager's mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during the summer. Families often come in late, so I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to get dressed up, people now wear jeans and khakis. I think the biggest change I've noticed is that the church I know doesn't involve me in its politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by changing policies like allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry. There are married men who become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. It's the individual, not the policies. I think that if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should consider a different faith. The sexuality of these priests might be based on genetics, not how they were brought up. I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening if they didn't know about it and were trying to cover it up. Shame on them if they did know and didn't act. As for other thoughts, I don't have any.

(laughs)

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still very much shaken by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq based on flimsy pretexts. Early on, the Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which turned out to be false.

That really rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war still upsets me. It seems to me that the Bush administration was very open about deceiving the American people and has yet to take responsibility. Even Colin Powell, who later admitted that he wasn’t convinced by the evidence when he presented it to the UN, called it a mistake.

That’s an impeachable offense, in my opinion. The Bush administration has shown complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to undermine it since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t remember the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made that allegation in his book after he was likely forced out of office, but it seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly due to his father’s administration. I think he also aimed to secure our energy supply, which is a very underhanded approach.

I think we should have pulled out a long time ago. Pulling out now could lead to a civil war, which would result in more deaths. The alternative proposed by the UN and the US, a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the best idea because it could also lead to long-term issues regarding Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, and the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister lacks control, and radical elements are vying for power.

I really don’t feel that it’s appropriate to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. I think it’s up to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. I feel that attempting to impose any kind of power over this issue would be against what has already been written in the constitution. I believe those trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in areas like Boston. I don’t think it’s the government’s place to decide what churches can and can’t make illegal. The separation of church and state is a key aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the United States. Even if an amendment were to be made, I think it would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don’t think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don’t see why he’s pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. I really feel it’s up to the churches, not the president or anyone in government, to decide this. There isn’t a good reason for an amendment banning it, as I don’t see how it would impact the economy or society positively.

Ok, the war in Iraq.

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which, in reality, had little to do with each other. The government exploited the public's outrage against the attacks to push for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I myself am strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes. The war in Iraq, in many ways, is reminiscent of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes, such as the high number of American soldiers who died. They removed Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath, including the power vacuum and chaos that ensued. The United States was attempting to install a democratic government, similar to their efforts in Vietnam. However, the government underestimated the difficulty and duration of the process.

I believe the government was not adequately prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We are still there, at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. The long process of training Iraqi troops and police forces is ongoing. The government may have tried to deceive the American people into believing it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. Implementing a new form of government takes years and is not an easy process, as seen in our own history.

The decision to go to war is difficult. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken away their government and way of life. However, we also need to consider the high risk and cost to American lives. Moreover, if the goal is to create a democratic nation, why just Iraq? The main reason is likely oil, as it's a significant source of our energy. The government's claims of Iraq having weapons of mass destruction turned out to be false, unlike in the case of North Korea, where we know they exist but have not attacked.

I hope that this war ends soon and that there will be peace, but I doubt that will happen.

I feel like the war has been prolonged for too long. Initially, the purpose was good, which was to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have lost sight of that purpose and are now fighting for the sake of proving our power. I think the original motivation had questionable aspects, such as George Bush's father's previous disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be justifiable, but if personal matters were involved, it would not be fair. I believe the war has been prolonged too much. Initially, starting the war was a clear statement, but it has dragged on for over a year now. If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I don't think our reason has remained consistent over time; it seems we are still at war just to be at war, and we don't want to leave without a decisive victory. I think the war has gone on long enough and should stop. There comes a point when the country's officials must fend for themselves. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions of dollars on this war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty. This war is a long-term drain on our economy. We should be spending that money on improving our own country, such as fixing roads and schools, and addressing healthcare issues. Right now, that money is being spent to kill our own citizens in a war we've lost the cause for. I think that's it.

My understanding is that they did not legalize it; they decriminalized it. This means it was reduced from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—something you might get cited for instead of being booked and arrested. When someone gets caught and cited for it, there are still potential ramifications, such as issues with job interviews and other formal situations, which are usually the worst effects of a drug charge. At least with a marijuana charge, people often worry about these long-term effects, even if it's decriminalized.

However, there's an argument that arresting and processing people can be expensive. It involves costs for booking, housing, court proceedings, and legal representation. Municipalities facing financial difficulties might not be willing to take on these additional expenses, even if it could free up funding for other public needs. In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it might be accepted. Here, the city might have more money to spend on education, social programs, and food assistance for the homeless due to the financial benefits.

I don't think everyone wants marijuana to be widely available and smoked everywhere, as it could be awkward and not socially accepted in many places. Additionally, it's hard to generalize about the effects of substances like marijuana and alcohol. They both have adverse effects on people, and individuals react differently based on their personal characteristics. Some people might use substances moderately, while others might not. Ultimately, both substances can have negative impacts, but how they affect each other can vary greatly from person to person.

I was raised in a Christian family, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle. I believe that gay marriage should be legalized because there is no valid reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is not the case. There are so many factors to consider that it cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin - heads can never be tails, but they are essentially the same. There are various civil rights associated with this, such as property taxes and healthcare, where a partner cannot be present if you are sick, as they are not technically considered family. I think this is absurd if you are spending the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar rates of success and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. It's just a relationship, and it's the same thing. What many people seem to get hung up on is that homosexuals are not asking for the right to get married in a church, but rather a legal marriage certificate provided by the government. If there is no involvement with church and state, this shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why people like Catholics would object to this on religious grounds, as it is a legal matter. If you are allowing someone a civil union, why not also allow them a legal marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. I think the federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state, and the amendment should reflect this. However, I think President Bush has strong views on this matter, and his stance on gay marriage aligns with his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard against it are moral, but morality differs from person to person. To embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest is unethical. It's hypocritical for the government to create an amendment banning gay marriage while considering recent controversies such as the pledge of allegiance. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe gay people are psychologically damaged, but this is not a valid reason. The American Psychological Association has stated that this is untrue. Institutions that actually do research should be listened to instead of popular opinion or religious beliefs.

First off, I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. You know, just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it has beneficial properties. So, I’d say no to making it available to the public. Absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I’d say yes. Because just because a drug is illegal doesn’t mean it’s beneficial; it’s not beneficial. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are a bunch of drugs that are illegal but pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Perocets, that kind of thing. And those are controlled substances. But we use them all the time because they’re beneficial. And if you deny that, just because there’s a taboo around marijuana, then there’s no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don’t think it’s that similar to alcohol because if you abuse marijuana, although if you abuse alcohol too, that can lead to bad things. It’s a tough one. I’d say you could integrate it, like let it become legal gradually but not all at once. Because then it would be abused, but if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it’s an illegal drug. But I mean, it’s not that bad for you. It’s not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. So, I mean, if we get rid of that image of marijuana as being this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly. And certainly for medical purposes.

I think the church has already changed to adapt to the twenty-first century. It's not as strict as it used to be. I remember growing up, I would always go to church every Sunday and wear cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. I went to a private school, and I would see all my friends there on the weekends. Now, as I've gotten older, they've started a teenager's mass that's only thirty minutes long. People dress more casually, especially during the summer. Families often come in late, so I think it has become more casual. Even at the morning masses where I used to get dressed up, people now wear jeans and khakis. I think the biggest change I've noticed is that the church I know doesn't involve me in its politics.

Regarding the accusations against Catholic priests dealing with pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by changing policies like allowing female priests or allowing priests to marry. There are married men who become pedophiles, and they still have an attraction towards young kids. It's the individual, not the policies. I think that if they really wanted to practice their faith and be married at the same time, they should consider a different faith. The sexuality of these priests might be based on genetics, not how they were brought up. I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent this from happening if they didn't know about it and were trying to cover it up. Shame on them if they did know and didn't act. As for other thoughts, I don't have any.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I think everyone was still very much shaken by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq based on flimsy pretexts. Early on, the Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which turned out to be false.

That really rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war still upsets me. It seems to me that the Bush administration was very open about deceiving the American people and has yet to take responsibility. Even Colin Powell, who later admitted that he wasn’t convinced by the evidence when he presented it to the UN, called it a mistake.

That’s an impeachable offense, in my opinion. The Bush administration has shown complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to undermine it since September 11th at least. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

I can’t remember the name of the Secretary of the Treasury who made that allegation in his book after he was likely forced out of office, but it seems that the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly due to his father’s administration. I think he also aimed to secure our energy supply, which is a very underhanded approach.

I think we should have pulled out a long time ago. Pulling out now could lead to a civil war, which would result in more deaths. The alternative proposed by the UN and the US, a coalition of nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the best idea because it could also lead to long-term issues regarding Iraq’s sovereignty. The interim government seems to be falling apart, and the Parliament isn’t very effective. The Prime Minister lacks control, and radical elements are vying for power.

I really don’t feel that it’s appropriate to make it legal or for a state to declare it legal. I think it’s up to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. I feel that attempting to impose any kind of power over this issue would be against what has already been written in the constitution. I believe those trying to make it illegal are choosing one church's beliefs over others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except in areas like Boston. I don’t think it’s the government’s place to decide what churches can and can’t make illegal. The separation of church and state is a key aspect of the constitution, promoting religious tolerance in the United States. Even if an amendment were to be made, I think it would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already written. Plus, I believe it would be one of the few amendments used to restrict people rather than the government. I don’t think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I don’t see why he’s pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. I really feel it’s up to the churches, not the president or anyone in government, to decide this. There isn’t a good reason for an amendment banning it, as I don’t see how it would impact the economy or society positively.

Ok, the war in Iraq.

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which, in reality, had little to do with each other. The government exploited the public's outrage against the attacks to push for the invasion, which began in 2003.

I myself am strongly against war, especially preemptive strikes. The war in Iraq, in many ways, is reminiscent of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes, such as the high number of American soldiers who died. They removed Iraq's government without being prepared for the aftermath, including the power vacuum and chaos that ensued. The United States was attempting to install a democratic government, similar to their efforts in Vietnam. However, the government underestimated the difficulty and duration of the process.

I believe the government was not adequately prepared for what would happen after removing the Iraqi government. We are still there, at the end of 2006, and American troops are still dying. The long process of training Iraqi troops and police forces is ongoing. The government may have tried to deceive the American people into believing it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. Implementing a new form of government takes years and is not an easy process, as seen in our own history.

The decision to go to war is difficult. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken away their government and way of life. However, we also need to consider the high risk and cost to American lives. Moreover, if the goal is to create a democratic nation, why just Iraq? The main reason is likely oil, as it's a significant source of our energy. The government's claims of Iraq having weapons of mass destruction turned out to be false, unlike in the case of North Korea, where we know they exist but have not attacked.

I hope that this war ends soon and that there will be peace, but I doubt that will happen.

I feel like the war has been prolonged for too long. Initially, the purpose was good, which was to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have lost sight of that purpose and are now fighting for the sake of proving our power. I think the original motivation had questionable aspects, such as George Bush's father's previous disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the intention was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would be justifiable, but if personal matters were involved, it would not be fair. I believe the war has been prolonged too much. Initially, starting the war was a clear statement, but it has dragged on for over a year now. If our purpose was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I don't think our reason has remained consistent over time; it seems we are still at war just to be at war, and we don't want to leave without a decisive victory. I think the war has gone on long enough and should stop. There comes a point when the country's officials must fend for themselves. We've been draining our own economy by spending billions of dollars on this war while facing our own domestic issues like poverty. This war is a long-term drain on our economy. We should be spending that money on improving our own country, such as fixing roads and schools, and addressing healthcare issues. Right now, that money is being spent to kill our own citizens in a war we've lost the cause for. I think that's it.

My understanding is that they did not legalize it; they decriminalized it. This means it was reduced from a criminal offense to something more like a traffic ticket—something you might get cited for instead of being booked and arrested. When someone gets caught and cited for it, there are still potential ramifications, such as issues with job interviews and other formal situations, which are usually the worst effects of a drug charge. At least with a marijuana charge, people often worry about these long-term effects, even if it's decriminalized.

However, there's an argument that arresting and processing people can be expensive. It involves costs for booking, housing, court proceedings, and legal representation. Municipalities facing financial difficulties might not be willing to take on these additional expenses, even if it could free up funding for other public needs. In a place like Denver, where people are more open-minded, it might be accepted. Here, the city might have more money to spend on education, social programs, and food assistance for the homeless due to the financial benefits.

I don't think everyone wants marijuana to be widely available and smoked everywhere, as it could be awkward and not socially accepted in many places. Additionally, it's hard to generalize about the effects of substances like marijuana and alcohol. They both have adverse effects on people, and individuals react differently based on their personal characteristics. Some people might use substances moderately, while others might not. Ultimately, both substances can have negative impacts, but how they affect each other can vary greatly from person to person.

I was raised in a Christian family, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe that it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. I feel that it should be decided by each state rather than the president deciding for the whole country.

Many states are democratic, and many are republican. Democratic states will likely push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. I don't think you should disagree with a state's decision if they choose to legalize it, as you chose to live there. I think homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel like it should be legalized based on each state's discretion.

I've already answered that. But I don't feel like Bush should be able to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think some things should be left up to each individual state, as they're the ones who will have to live with the decision. Plus, he'll be out of office in two years. If a democratic president decides to lift the ban, it will just go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones who will have to live with the decision, not the president.

transformed_texts: I think that in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to change. Their views are somewhat outdated, and many people are turning away from it. For instance, the Church is not very accepting of topics like same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These strong views can be seen as old-fashioned. If the Church adapted to more modern thinking, it might not face a loss of followers. I've heard that many people are unsatisfied with the Church's stance on these issues. They feel that the Church's views are incorrect. For example, if someone supports abortion and wants to stay within the Church, it might make them uncomfortable if the Church teaches it's completely wrong. The same goes for same-sex marriage. People might not want to follow a religion that disagrees with their personal beliefs. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or why women can't become priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the current situation. It's hard to say if priests would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. The Church argues that priests are devoted to God, but I don't see why they can't also have a family life. It's perplexing that priests can't balance their job and their personal life like everyone else.

I am not opposed to gay marriage. I think that whether you're born that way or not, it's not a choice. I don't think people, like gay people, should be held responsible for their sexual orientation. It's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't given the topic much thought, but I would definitely say that's wrong. It's not like they have a choice in how they are born. I mean, I was born straight and another person could be born gay, it doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice that they should be held responsible for. I wouldn't think it's wrong to do that. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal or moral issue. It doesn't seem like they have any right to interject in people's lives. That's just who they are, and they shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

Ok.
The war in Iraq.
Well,
To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was entirely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which in reality had little to do with each other. But the government made it seem otherwise and played on the emotions of the American people still outraged by the 9/11 attacks, and the invasion of Iraq began in 2003.
Um,
I,
I myself am generally against war, especially a preemptive strike. I think the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.
A tremendous number of American soldiers have died, and that’s horrible. What they were doing is that they were removing the country’s government and I really don’t think the American government was prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that ensued. And here, the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, a similar thing they tried to do in Vietnam by pushing out Communists and upholding democracy.
But it's not going to be a clear victory like it wasn’t in Vietnam because there are insurgents, and it’s hard to put them down when you’re not fighting an actual army, you’re fighting citizens.
So, I think first of all, we shouldn’t have gotten into war in the first place, cause I’m against it in pretty much all cases. But if you’re going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government wasn’t prepared enough for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and we’re still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police to be able to police their own country. It’s a long process.
I think the U.S. government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about that because implementing a new form of government takes years, and it’s not an easy thing to do. It was a long struggle in our own country to get to the powerful government we are today, with lots of tension and even civil war.
So, the war in Iraq, it’s a difficult decision. It was kind of my feeling in the 2004 presidential election when I was thinking about who I would vote for. One of my reasons to vote for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. But once you go in, how can you abandon them? We took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? It’s probably something we should try to see through to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical number of American casualties.
I mean, if we’re invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why just Iraq? Why not all these other countries? I think the big reason is the oil issue, and this is where we’re getting our oil from. It’s usually about money and controlling resources.
And another thing to consider is that before going into war, it was said that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no weapons were ever found. Places like North Korea, we know they have weapons of mass destruction, but we’re not making any attacks against them. So, I don’t think the U.S. government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

When you post something online, it enters a public forum. It's completely public. You can't control what others think or do. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. When you put something out there, it shapes people's opinions about you. If you're talking about destruction or shootings, someone might react. You can't put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you might receive a bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin; someone went to the school and reported it. They have to act on it, because if they don't and something happens, they could have prevented it. However, you don't know what to take seriously, because some people just joke around. Like in our school, it could have been a sociology project gone wrong. I mean, what happened was someone overheard something in the school and reported it. When we found out who the person was, a friend of his checked his Facebook and got worried because there were some concerning messages. In light of the situation, it became serious. When you put something online, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. You can't control what others think or find. I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook. But if something is brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, I don't think they should monitor phone conversations and texts. But if something is brought to their attention, it's a different story. Like a teacher shouldn't create a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and befriend students. That's the same as not wanting to know your residents if they go out and drink and post pictures on Facebook. It's not my place to know that, so I don't want that connection.

Ich weiß nicht, ob das ein Problem der Privatsphäre ist ...
Aber ich denke ...
Ich weiß es nicht wirklich ...
Wie sie das Recht hatten, das zu verlangen.

Das ist der einzige Gedanke, der mir dazu einfällt.

My understanding is that they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This moved it down from a criminal offense to more of a traffic ticket. It's something you get cited for, instead of being arrested and brought in. If someone gets caught and cited, for job interviews and other things like that, the consequences which are usually the worst part of having a drug charge, don't necessarily go away when it's decriminalized. However, the argument is that it costs a lot to arrest people, bring them in, book them, house them, and go through the court process. This includes paying for public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office. So, when looking at financially troubled municipalities, many aren't willing to make this kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. However, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense. The municipality now has more money to spend on public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's important because you don't want marijuana to be everywhere, all over the streets. There are other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized. For example, if it were completely legalized, it could be sold in gas stations, and people would be smoking it everywhere. That could lead to a lot of people smoking and driving, which is still taboo in many places. I also feel that it would be awkward for people. In terms of their effects, alcohol has more debilitating effects on motor skills, but marijuana has a more adverse effect on one's lifestyle. Both have their adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people exercise moderation, while others don't. It makes it hard to generalize about the substance because people react differently. However, I definitely think they both have their own adverse effects.

I was raised in a Christian household, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don’t necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue, but rather something that each state decides on its own. The president shouldn’t decide for the entire country.

Many states are democratic, and many are republican. Democratic states will push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. You chose to live there, so you shouldn’t disagree with that decision if the state decides to legalize gay marriage.

I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don’t think the president should decide for the entire country. I don’t agree with his ban on it. He doesn’t live in every state, so he shouldn’t be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he’ll be out of office in a couple of years. If a democratic president wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth. It should be up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will have to live with the decision, not the president.

transformed_texts: I think that in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to change. Their views are somewhat outdated, and many people are turning away from it. For instance, the Church is not very accepting of topics like same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These strong views can be seen as old-fashioned. If the Church adapted to more modern thinking, it might not face a loss of followers. I've heard that many people are unsatisfied with the Church's stance on these issues. They feel that the Church's views are incorrect. For example, if someone supports abortion and wants to stay within the Church, it might make them uncomfortable if the Church teaches it's completely wrong. The same goes for same-sex marriage. People might not want to follow a religion that disagrees with their personal beliefs. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or why women can't become priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the current situation. It's hard to say if priests would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. The Church argues that priests are devoted to God, but I don't see why they can't also have a family life. It's perplexing that priests can't balance their job and their personal life like everyone else.

I am not opposed to gay marriage. I think that whether you're born that way or not, it's not a choice. I don't think people, like gay people, should be held responsible for their sexual orientation. It's wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't given the topic much thought, but I would definitely say that's wrong. It's not like they have a choice in how they are born. I mean, I was born straight and another person could be born gay, it doesn't seem like it's a conscious choice that they should be held responsible for. I wouldn't think it's wrong to do that. I don't think the federal government should be involved because it's not a legal or moral issue. It doesn't seem like they have any right to interject in people's lives. That's just who they are, and they shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

Ok.
The war in Iraq.
Well,
To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was entirely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which in reality had little to do with each other. But the government made it seem otherwise and played on the emotions of the American people still outraged by the 9/11 attacks, and the invasion of Iraq began in 2003.
Um,
I,
I myself am generally against war, especially a preemptive strike. I think the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.
A tremendous number of American soldiers have died, and that’s horrible. What they were doing is that they were removing the country’s government and I really don’t think the American government was prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that ensued. And here, the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, a similar thing they tried to do in Vietnam by pushing out Communists and upholding democracy.
But it's not going to be a clear victory like it wasn’t in Vietnam because there are insurgents, and it’s hard to put them down when you’re not fighting an actual army, you’re fighting citizens.
So, I think first of all, we shouldn’t have gotten into war in the first place, cause I’m against it in pretty much all cases. But if you’re going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government wasn’t prepared enough for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and we’re still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police to be able to police their own country. It’s a long process.
I think the U.S. government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about that because implementing a new form of government takes years, and it’s not an easy thing to do. It was a long struggle in our own country to get to the powerful government we are today, with lots of tension and even civil war.
So, the war in Iraq, it’s a difficult decision. It was kind of my feeling in the 2004 presidential election when I was thinking about who I would vote for. One of my reasons to vote for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. But once you go in, how can you abandon them? We took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? It’s probably something we should try to see through to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical number of American casualties.
I mean, if we’re invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why just Iraq? Why not all these other countries? I think the big reason is the oil issue, and this is where we’re getting our oil from. It’s usually about money and controlling resources.
And another thing to consider is that before going into war, it was said that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no weapons were ever found. Places like North Korea, we know they have weapons of mass destruction, but we’re not making any attacks against them. So, I don’t think the U.S. government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

When you post something online, it enters a public forum. It's completely public. You can't control what others think or do. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. When you put something out there, it shapes people's opinions about you. If you're talking about destruction or shootings, someone might react. You can't put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you might receive a bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin; someone went to the school and reported it. They have to act on it, because if they don't and something happens, they could have prevented it. However, you don't know what to take seriously, because some people just joke around. Like in our school, it could have been a sociology project gone wrong. I mean, what happened was someone overheard something in the school and reported it. When we found out who the person was, a friend of his checked his Facebook and got worried because there were some concerning messages. In light of the situation, it became serious. When you put something online, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. You can't control what others think or find. I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook. But if something is brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, I don't think they should monitor phone conversations and texts. But if something is brought to their attention, it's a different story. Like a teacher shouldn't create a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and befriend students. That's the same as not wanting to know your residents if they go out and drink and post pictures on Facebook. It's not my place to know that, so I don't want that connection.

Um ...
Ich meine, ich denke, das wäre nicht richtig, eine Person zu haben, die die Profile der anderen durchsucht.
Aber das hängt alles davon ab ...
Von der Situation, auf die sie gestoßen sind, oder war jemand nur zufällig dabei, die Profile zu durchsuchen ...
Oder suchten sie nach Beweisen, dass der Schüler etwas plant ...

Um.
Nun, ich habe persönlich kein Myspace, aber ich habe ein Facebook.
Es stört mich, dass ich weiß, dass es da draußen merkwürdige Leute gibt ...
Die wissen können, was über mich.
Und ich habe einmal etwas im Fernsehen gesehen, das über diesen Mann handelte ...
Der nur beweisen wollte, wie leicht es ist, Informationen zu erhalten.
Und er ging auf das Profil eines Mädchens und hatte ihren Nicknamen sofort.
Und unterhielt sich in weniger als einer Minute mit ihr per Instant Messenger und konnte sie dazu bringen, sich mit ihm zu treffen.
Und ich meine ...
Persönlich würde ich mich sicher nicht mit jemandem treffen ...
Aber ich habe in meinen Kursen Menschen, die ich nicht wiedererkenne ...
Die mir aber eine Nachricht senden und wissen, dass ich es bin.
Und es ist schwer, weil man denkt, dass sie wissen, was man interessiert ...
Welches Aussehen man hat ...
Manchmal, wenn man den Stundenplan hochlädt, wissen sie, wo man den ganzen Tag ist ...
Wer die Freunde sind ...
Und sie wissen im Grunde genommen viel über einen.
Und ich habe versucht, das, was ich hochlade, einzuschränken ...
Aber gleichzeitig ...
Ich denke, der Grund, warum ich eines habe, ist, dass ich mit einigen meiner Freunde kommunizieren kann ...
Ich will es nicht zu sehr einschränken.
Also ist es ein schwieriges Thema.
Denn ich nehme nur Leute an, die ich kenne ...
Ich meine, man weiß nie wirklich, wer auf was zugreifen kann.

Ich war mir nicht sicher, wie ...
Wie die Schulleitung das Recht hatte, ihren Schülern zu sagen ...
Dass sie keinen Myspace haben durften.

Und ...
Ich weiß nicht, ob das ein Problem der Privatsphäre ist ...
Aber ich denke ...
Ich weiß es nicht wirklich ...
Wie sie das Recht hatten, das zu verlangen.

Das ist der einzige Gedanke, der mir dazu einfällt.

My understanding is that they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This moved it down from a criminal offense to more of a traffic ticket. It's something you get cited for, instead of being arrested and brought in. If someone gets caught and cited, for job interviews and other things like that, the consequences which are usually the worst part of having a drug charge, don't necessarily go away when it's decriminalized. However, the argument is that it costs a lot to arrest people, bring them in, book them, house them, and go through the court process. This includes paying for public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office. So, when looking at financially troubled municipalities, many aren't willing to make this kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. However, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense. The municipality now has more money to spend on public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's important because you don't want marijuana to be everywhere, all over the streets. There are other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized. For example, if it were completely legalized, it could be sold in gas stations, and people would be smoking it everywhere. That could lead to a lot of people smoking and driving, which is still taboo in many places. I also feel that it would be awkward for people. In terms of their effects, alcohol has more debilitating effects on motor skills, but marijuana has a more adverse effect on one's lifestyle. Both have their adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people exercise moderation, while others don't. It makes it hard to generalize about the substance because people react differently. However, I definitely think they both have their own adverse effects.

I was raised in a Christian household, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don’t necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue, but rather something that each state decides on its own. The president shouldn’t decide for the entire country.

Many states are democratic, and many are republican. Democratic states will push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. You chose to live there, so you shouldn’t disagree with that decision if the state decides to legalize gay marriage.

I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don’t think the president should decide for the entire country. I don’t agree with his ban on it. He doesn’t live in every state, so he shouldn’t be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he’ll be out of office in a couple of years. If a democratic president wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth. It should be up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will have to live with the decision, not the president.

transformed_texts: I think that in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to change. Their views are somewhat outdated, and many people are turning away from it. For instance, the Church is not very accepting of topics like same-sex marriage, abortion, and birth control. These strong views can be seen as old-fashioned. If the Church adapted to more modern thinking, it might not face a loss of followers. I've heard that many people are unsatisfied with the Church's stance on these issues. They feel that the Church's views are incorrect. For example, if someone supports abortion and wants to stay within the Church, it might make them uncomfortable if the Church teaches it's completely wrong. The same goes for same-sex marriage. People might not want to follow a religion that disagrees with their personal beliefs. I don't see any reason why priests can't be married or why women can't become priests. However, I'm not sure if these changes would have prevented the current situation. It's hard to say if priests would have acted differently if they were allowed to be married or if there were women priests. Ok.
The war in Iraq.
Well,
To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was entirely honest with the American people about the reasons for war before invading Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, which in reality had little to do with each other. But the government made it seem otherwise and played on the emotions of the American people still outraged by the 9/11 attacks, and the invasion of Iraq began in 2003.
Um,
I,
I myself am generally against war, especially a preemptive strike. I think the war in Iraq is, in many ways, a repeat of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes.
A tremendous number of American soldiers have died, and that’s horrible. What they were doing is that they were removing the country’s government and I really don’t think the American government was prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that ensued. And here, the United States is removing the Iraqi government and trying to implant a democratic government, a similar thing they tried to do in Vietnam by pushing out Communists and upholding democracy.
But it's not going to be a clear victory like it wasn’t in Vietnam because there are insurgents, and it’s hard to put them down when you’re not fighting an actual army, you’re fighting citizens.
So, I think first of all, we shouldn’t have gotten into war in the first place, cause I’m against it in pretty much all cases. But if you’re going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government wasn’t prepared enough for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and we’re still trying to train the Iraqi troops and police to be able to police their own country. It’s a long process.
I think the U.S. government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about that because implementing a new form of government takes years, and it’s not an easy thing to do. It was a long struggle in our own country to get to the powerful government we are today, with lots of tension and even civil war.
So, the war in Iraq, it’s a difficult decision. It was kind of my feeling in the 2004 presidential election when I was thinking about who I would vote for. One of my reasons to vote for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. But once you go in, how can you abandon them? We took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? It’s probably something we should try to see through to its finish, but there’s also the consideration of the astronomical number of American casualties.
I mean, if we’re invading Iraq to make it a democratic nation, why just Iraq? Why not all these other countries? I think the big reason is the oil issue, and this is where we’re getting our oil from. It’s usually about money and controlling resources.
And another thing to consider is that before going into war, it was said that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no weapons were ever found. Places like North Korea, we know they have weapons of mass destruction, but we’re not making any attacks against them. So, I don’t think the U.S. government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

When you post something online, it enters a public forum. It's completely public. You can't control what others think or do. As an R.A., I've had to deal with this. When you put something out there, it shapes people's opinions about you. If you're talking about destruction or shootings, someone might react. You can't put that out there for the world to see. The internet is accessible to everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace, you might receive a bulletin. It wasn't the school that received the bulletin; someone went to the school and reported it. They have to act on it, because if they don't and something happens, they could have prevented it. However, you don't know what to take seriously, because some people just joke around. Like in our school, it could have been a sociology project gone wrong. I mean, what happened was someone overheard something in the school and reported it. When we found out who the person was, a friend of his checked his Facebook and got worried because there were some concerning messages. In light of the situation, it became serious. When you put something online, there's no invasion of privacy. If you don't want it out there, don't put it there. You can't control what others think or find. I don't think school officials should be friends with students on Myspace and Facebook. But if something is brought to their attention, there's no invasion of privacy. If there's danger, they have to take it seriously. I mean, I don't think they should monitor phone conversations and texts. But if something is brought to their attention, it's a different story. Like a teacher shouldn't create a Facebook or Myspace account under a different name and befriend students. That's the same as not wanting to know your residents if they go out and drink and post pictures on Facebook. It's not my place to know that, so I don't want that connection.

My understanding is that they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. This moved it down from a criminal offense to more of a traffic ticket. It's something you get cited for, instead of being arrested and brought in. If someone gets caught and cited, for job interviews and other things like that, the consequences which are usually the worst part of having a drug charge, don't necessarily go away when it's decriminalized. However, the argument is that it costs a lot to arrest people, bring them in, book them, house them, and go through the court process. This includes paying for public defenders, judges, and the state attorney's office. So, when looking at financially troubled municipalities, many aren't willing to make this kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. However, in a place like Denver, where people tend to be more open-minded, it makes sense. The municipality now has more money to spend on public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. It's important because you don't want marijuana to be everywhere, all over the streets. There are other reasons why it shouldn't necessarily be legalized. For example, if it were completely legalized, it could be sold in gas stations, and people would be smoking it everywhere. That could lead to a lot of people smoking and driving, which is still taboo in many places. I also feel that it would be awkward for people. In terms of their effects, alcohol has more debilitating effects on motor skills, but marijuana has a more adverse effect on one's lifestyle. Both have their adverse effects, and no two people react the same way. Some people exercise moderation, while others don't. It makes it hard to generalize about the substance because people react differently. However, I definitely think they both have their own adverse effects.

I was raised in a Christian household, so homosexuality is a bit of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, but I don’t necessarily agree with their lifestyle. However, I believe it should be legalized. I don’t think it should be a national issue, but rather something that each state decides on its own. The president shouldn’t decide for the entire country.

Many states are democratic, and many are republican. Democratic states will push for gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about the issue. You chose to live there, so you shouldn’t disagree with that decision if the state decides to legalize gay marriage.

I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don’t think the president should decide for the entire country. I don’t agree with his ban on it. He doesn’t live in every state, so he shouldn’t be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he’ll be out of office in a couple of years. If a democratic president wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it will just go back and forth. It should be up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will have to live with the decision, not the president.

The Church may have done things differently if they were allowed more freedom, but it's hard to say for sure. I don't understand why priests can't be married, as everyone else has jobs and family lives, and it wouldn't prevent them from being devoted to their work and God.

I believe that same-sex marriage should be legalized. There isn’t a compelling reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples threaten the heterosexual family, but that's a simplistic view. Same-sex relationships are fundamentally different and have various aspects that make them distinct. It's like two sides of the same coin – heads won't ever be tails, but they're essentially the same. Many civil rights, such as property taxes and healthcare, are intertwined with marriage. For instance, if you're part of a same-sex couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be your next of kin because they're not legally considered family. This seems unfair if you're spending the rest of your life with someone. Numerous studies have shown that same-sex couples have similar relationship satisfaction rates as heterosexual couples. The key issue is that same-sex couples are not asking for the right to marry in a church; they want a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If there's no church involvement, this shouldn't be a problem. I can't understand why people, like Catholics, refuse to acknowledge this. If you allow same-sex couples civil unions, why not allow them marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal. They're the same in many ways, like relationship dynamics. Adoption and community issues are also concerns, but children of same-sex couples will grow up with the same parenting skills and potential for societal acceptance as children of heterosexual couples. I believe the federal government should legalize same-sex marriage across all states. I'm uncertain about President Bush's stance on the issue, as his views appear to be influenced by his religious beliefs, much like his views on abortion and stem cell research. The main reason I've heard against same-sex marriage is moral opposition, but morality can differ greatly among individuals and groups. It's unethical to ignore the cultural and moral perspectives of the majority of Americans while basing laws on the beliefs of a religious minority. Additionally, many people oppose same-sex marriage due to the belief that gay people are psychologically damaged, which is not backed by scientific evidence. The American Psychological Association has debunked this notion. We should rely on scientific institutions for information rather than popular opinion or cultural norms.
