I feel really strongly that it’s not right for it to be made legal or for a state to even declare it as legal. I think it should be left to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any kind of power over this would go against what’s already been written in stone. I think those who are trying to make it illegal are choosing one church’s beliefs over another, since most Catholics and Christians are against it. I don’t think it’s up to the government to decide what churches can and can’t do. The separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution and is fundamental to religious tolerance in the US. Making an amendment about this would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already been stated in the constitution. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that restrict people rather than the government. I don’t feel it’s right for the federal government or any government to be involved in this issue. I don’t see why the president is pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. It should be up to the churches to decide this, not the president or anyone in government. There isn’t any reason backing it other than personal views. I don’t see how it will impact the economy or society. If anything, it could have a positive impact on society. I think I’ve pretty much said it all.

If the Church were to adapt to more modern thinking, it would likely not worry about losing its following. I've heard that some people are starting to turn away from the Church due to its views on these issues. Many people disagree with the Church's positions on certain topics. For example, if someone supports abortion, they may feel uncomfortable in a community where it is considered completely wrong. Similarly, if someone believes in and wants to pursue gay marriage, they might not want to be part of a community that doesn't support it. I don't see any reason why the Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married, but I'm not sure if that would have prevented the problems that arose. The Church may have done things differently if they were allowed more freedom, but it's hard to say for sure. I don't understand why priests can't be married, as everyone else has jobs and family lives, and it wouldn't prevent them from being devoted to their work and God.

I believe that same-sex marriage should be legalized. There isn’t a compelling reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples threaten the heterosexual family, but that's a simplistic view. Same-sex relationships are fundamentally different and have various aspects that make them distinct. It's like two sides of the same coin – heads won't ever be tails, but they're essentially the same. Many civil rights, such as property taxes and healthcare, are intertwined with marriage. For instance, if you're part of a same-sex couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be your next of kin because they're not legally considered family. This seems unfair if you're spending the rest of your life with someone. Numerous studies have shown that same-sex couples have similar relationship satisfaction rates as heterosexual couples. The key issue is that same-sex couples are not asking for the right to marry in a church; they want a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If there's no church involvement, this shouldn't be a problem. I can't understand why people, like Catholics, refuse to acknowledge this. If you allow same-sex couples civil unions, why not allow them marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal. They're the same in many ways, like relationship dynamics. Adoption and community issues are also concerns, but children of same-sex couples will grow up with the same parenting skills and potential for societal acceptance as children of heterosexual couples. I believe the federal government should legalize same-sex marriage across all states. I'm uncertain about President Bush's stance on the issue, as his views appear to be influenced by his religious beliefs, much like his views on abortion and stem cell research. The main reason I've heard against same-sex marriage is moral opposition, but morality can differ greatly among individuals and groups. It's unethical to ignore the cultural and moral perspectives of the majority of Americans while basing laws on the beliefs of a religious minority. Additionally, many people oppose same-sex marriage due to the belief that gay people are psychologically damaged, which is not backed by scientific evidence. The American Psychological Association has debunked this notion. We should rely on scientific institutions for information rather than popular opinion or cultural norms.

The person was initially okay with the premise, but they think that everyone was still very much affected by the September 11th attacks and that the U.S. went into Iraq under the pretext of having weapons of mass destruction, which was later proven false. The Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama bin Laden and the September 11th attacks and claimed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which was all false. This rubbed the person the wrong way and they find the Iraq war very frustrating. They believe that the Bush administration lied to the American people and has not taken responsibility for this. Even Colin Powell, who gave a big presentation at the UN, admitted that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, which the person considers malfeasance in office and an impeachable offense. They believe that the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since September 11th. The person thinks the Bush administration came into office with the intent to go to war. They remember a Treasury Secretary who made these allegations in his book after being forced out. The person thinks the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his father's administration and was trying to expand U.S. energy supply in the long term, which is seen as underhanded. They think the situation has gone on long enough, but they worry about the problems if the U.S. withdraws now as it could lead to civil war and more deaths. They think the alternative, a coalition of nations from surrounding areas like Syria and Saudi Arabia, could also cause long-term problems because of sovereignty issues. They believe the interim government is dissolving and the parliament isn't very effective. They mention Mugtada al-Sadr's party now holding seats in the parliament and the political process experiencing friction due to radical elements vying for control.

I feel really strongly that it’s not right for it to be made legal or for a state to even declare it as legal. I think it should be left to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any kind of power over this would go against what’s already been written in stone. I think those who are trying to make it illegal are choosing one church’s beliefs over another, since most Catholics and Christians are against it. I don’t think it’s up to the government to decide what churches can and can’t do. The separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution and is fundamental to religious tolerance in the US. Making an amendment about this would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already been stated in the constitution. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that restrict people rather than the government. I don’t feel it’s right for the federal government or any government to be involved in this issue. I don’t see why the president is pushing for this amendment, except that it’s against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for this amendment shows a preference for one religion over others. It should be up to the churches to decide this, not the president or anyone in government. There isn’t any reason backing it other than personal views. I don’t see how it will impact the economy or society. If anything, it could have a positive impact on society. I think I’ve pretty much said it all.

transformed_texts: I believe that in several ways, the Catholic Church needs to change. Their views are outdated and not accepting of many things, such as gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. If the Church were to adapt to more modern thinking, it would likely not worry about losing its following. I've heard that some people are starting to turn away from the Church due to its views on these issues. Many people disagree with the Church's positions on certain topics. For example, if someone supports abortion, they may feel uncomfortable in a community where it is considered completely wrong. Similarly, if someone believes in and wants to pursue gay marriage, they might not want to be part of a community that doesn't support it. I don't see any reason why the Church can't have female priests or allow priests to be married, but I'm not sure if that would have prevented the problems that arose. The Church may have done things differently if they were allowed more freedom, but it's hard to say for sure. I don't understand why priests can't be married, as everyone else has jobs and family lives, and it wouldn't prevent them from being devoted to their work and God.

I believe that same-sex marriage should be legalized. There isn’t a compelling reason not to. Many people think that homosexual couples threaten the heterosexual family, but that's a simplistic view. Same-sex relationships are fundamentally different and have various aspects that make them distinct. It's like two sides of the same coin – heads won't ever be tails, but they're essentially the same. Many civil rights, such as property taxes and healthcare, are intertwined with marriage. For instance, if you're part of a same-sex couple, your partner can't visit you in the hospital or be your next of kin because they're not legally considered family. This seems unfair if you're spending the rest of your life with someone. Numerous studies have shown that same-sex couples have similar relationship satisfaction rates as heterosexual couples. The key issue is that same-sex couples are not asking for the right to marry in a church; they want a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government. If there's no church involvement, this shouldn't be a problem. I can't understand why people, like Catholics, refuse to acknowledge this. If you allow same-sex couples civil unions, why not allow them marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal. They're the same in many ways, like relationship dynamics. Adoption and community issues are also concerns, but children of same-sex couples will grow up with the same parenting skills and potential for societal acceptance as children of heterosexual couples. I believe the federal government should legalize same-sex marriage across all states. I'm uncertain about President Bush's stance on the issue, as his views appear to be influenced by his religious beliefs, much like his views on abortion and stem cell research. The main reason I've heard against same-sex marriage is moral opposition, but morality can differ greatly among individuals and groups. It's unethical to ignore the cultural and moral perspectives of the majority of Americans while basing laws on the beliefs of a religious minority. Additionally, many people oppose same-sex marriage due to the belief that gay people are psychologically damaged, which is not backed by scientific evidence. The American Psychological Association has debunked this notion. We should rely on scientific institutions for information rather than popular opinion or cultural norms.

The person was initially okay with the premise, but they think that everyone was still very much affected by the September 11th attacks and that the U.S. went into Iraq under the pretext of having weapons of mass destruction, which was later proven false. The Bush administration linked the Iraq war to Osama bin Laden and the September 11th attacks and claimed that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which was all false. This rubbed the person the wrong way and they find the Iraq war very frustrating. They believe that the Bush administration lied to the American people and has not taken responsibility for this. Even Colin Powell, who gave a big presentation at the UN, admitted that he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time, which the person considers malfeasance in office and an impeachable offense. They believe that the Bush administration has a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it since September 11th. The person thinks the Bush administration came into office with the intent to go to war. They remember a Treasury Secretary who made these allegations in his book after being forced out. The person thinks the younger Bush had a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein because of his father's administration and was trying to expand U.S. energy supply in the long term, which is seen as underhanded. They think the situation has gone on long enough, but they worry about the problems if the U.S. withdraws now as it could lead to civil war and more deaths. They think the alternative, a coalition of nations from surrounding areas like Syria and Saudi Arabia, could also cause long-term problems because of sovereignty issues. They believe the interim government is dissolving and the parliament isn't very effective. They mention Mugtada al-Sadr's party now holding seats in the parliament and the political process experiencing friction due to radical elements vying for control.

I feel really strongly that it’s not right for it to be made legal or for a state to even declare it as legal. I think it should be left to the churches, as the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any kind of power over this would go against what’s already been written in stone. I think those who are trying to make it illegal are choosing one church’s beliefs over another, since most Catholics and Christians are against it. I don’t think it’s up to the government to decide what churches can and can’t do. The separation of church and state has been a key aspect of the constitution and is fundamental to religious tolerance in the US. Making an amendment about this would be wrong and contradictory to what’s already been stated in the constitution. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that restrict people rather than the government. I don’t feel it’s right for the federal government or any government to be involved in this issue. I don’t see how it will impact the economy or society. If anything, it could have a positive impact on society. I think I’ve pretty much said it all.

I haven't really made up my mind on this issue yet. I can't say if either side is right or wrong, but I do believe this is the most challenging topic we're facing today. I'm not sure what I think, but I believe that all civil unions, I don't know whether marriage should be looked at and defined by the government, seeing as it is considered a sacrament. Well, people wouldn't get tax breaks or be looked at in any specific way by the government if they were baptized. So, if you're married, I think they should just view it as a civil union, because that's what it is - two people united together. And the fact that gay marriage, I mean, that would just be two people getting a civil union. Well, if all the states can come to a logical conclusion, then they should push to make it federal law, but a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is just ridiculous. It's not important enough to amend the constitution for something like this. It's just not large enough a cause to change the constitution to ban gay marriage. Simply put, no.

I think that same-sex marriage should be legalized because there is no good reason not to. Many people believe that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but these couples are different; they have so many diverse aspects that they cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin – heads and tails are not the same, but they are similar. In addition, there are several civil rights that come with marriage, such as property taxes and healthcare, where your partner cannot be with you when you're sick or cannot visit because they're not considered family. This seems silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. They're just relationships, the same thing. People often get hung up on the idea that homosexuals are asking for the right to marry in a church, but they're asking for a legal marriage certificate, a document provided by the government. If there's no church involvement, then it shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why some people, like Catholics, would say it's against their religion or morally wrong, especially when they're not being forced to participate in a church ceremony. If you allow someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the relationship roles played by different partners. People also worry about adoption issues and how gay couples living in their community will affect it, and about the children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society. However, I think the main issue is how children are treated by their peers and adults in society. In New York City, for example, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they often get bullied in public schools. I believe the federal government should make gay marriage legal in every state and that the amendment should be changed to allow it. President Bush has strong views on this issue, primarily based on his religious beliefs. His stance on this issue is similar to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard for opposition are moral reasons, and morality differs from person to person. It's unethical to embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. To create a law banning gay marriage based on the beliefs of religious groups is hypocritical, considering recent controversies like the "under God" pledge and the opposition to it. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe it's due to psychological damage from childhood trauma or personality defects. This is not accurate, according to the American Psychological Association. If people listened to institutions that research these topics instead of popular opinion, the world might be seen differently.

First off, I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and let me tell you, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has beneficial properties. I mean, if we were to make it available to the public, I'd say no, absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I'd say yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial at all. You get what I mean?

Yeah, I mean, there are plenty of drugs that are illegal that pharmacies use, like oxycotton, Vicodin, Percocets, stuff like that. Those are controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. If you deny those benefits just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then there's no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don't think it's that similar to alcohol. If you abuse it, then sure, alcohol can lead to bad things. But marijuana is a tough one. I'd say, not to legalize it all at once, but gradually, because then it might get abused. But if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly. People have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug, but it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. If we get rid of that image of marijuana as this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I believe that everyone was still reeling from the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. There were pretexts that led us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which has since proven false. This has always rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war has always gotten under my skin.

It just seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, who came back from his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn’t convinced by the evidence at the time. And to me, that’s just negligence in office; it’s an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has shown a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since September 11th. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

The last part, I forget the name of the secretary of the treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office. But it seems like the younger Bush kind of came in with a blood vengeance feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his dad’s administration, and I think in the long term, he was hoping to expand our energy supply, which is a very underhanded way to do things.

I feel like the war has gone on much longer than necessary. Initially, the purpose was clear: to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal and are now engaged in the conflict merely to demonstrate our power. It seems that the original motivations, including George Bush's father's past disagreements with Saddam Hussein, were questionable. If the aim was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would have been a justifiable cause. However, I do not believe personal matters were involved. I think our purpose was clear at the outset, but the war has dragged on far too long. The conflict has become a means in itself, and we are reluctant to end it without a decisive victory. It has gone on long enough, and it should stop. The Iraqi government will eventually have to stand on its own, and I believe that time has come. We are draining our own economy by spending billions on a war that has long lost its justification. While we struggle with issues like poverty and lack of infrastructure at home, we continue to pour resources into a war that should not be a long-term priority. Instead, we should be investing in our own citizens, improving our public roads, and ensuring access to healthcare.

I feel that there is still a problem with gender discrimination in the United States. It doesn't just affect women; it also depends on the specific field of work you're in. Overall, I think women have it harder because of the glass ceiling, where even if there is supposed to be equality, it's hard for many to work underneath a woman if they're a man, due to societal norms that have existed for so long. In the workplace, women often see jobs they can reach and have the qualifications for, but sometimes the board might not choose to promote them just because historically it hasn't been seen that women are usually in the upper echelons of the business world. The same goes for men, especially in fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. It's really uncommon to have a male parent staying at home, and often people look down on that because society thinks that men should be working and earning money for the family. It can be hard on men who have always dreamed of being with the children and helping to raise them, especially if the wife has a better job. In the fashion industry, people often don't take men seriously if they're straight because they have different lifestyles and people might question if they truly understand fashion for women. Depending on the field of work, there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. Changing it is difficult because society has a set mindset, and while we've come a long way from the 1800s, change is very slow. However, it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. It's also becoming more acceptable for men to be stay-at-home dads, as they realize that the woman might have the better job or wants to be the one working. In the fashion industry, people might think that men are listening to their female friends or wives and understand what they're talking about. So, you kind of have to promote the good qualities of those who are stereotypically against them, not by being too pushy, but by emphasizing their qualities. If you force it, people will resist, and we're already at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced. I don't think there's anything we can do right now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, people will resist. We've come a long way, and change takes time.

My understanding is that they didn’t legalize it; instead, they decriminalized it. This change knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more akin to a traffic violation. You know, something you get cited for rather than being booked and arrested and brought in. And if someone gets caught and cited, those consequences are usually less severe than a drug charge. For example, a marijuana charge can still have future implications, like when it comes to job interviews. While decriminalization doesn’t completely erase these worries, it can also be argued that it saves money on arrests, court appearances, and legal fees. Financial strain can sometimes lead municipalities to be unwilling to make such changes, especially in places where marijuana is widely opposed. However, in more open-minded communities like Denver, it’s generally accepted, and the municipality can then reallocate funds to education, social programs, and services for the elderly and homeless. I don’t think marijuana should be legal and easily accessible everywhere, as it could lead to excessive use and driving under the influence, which is still widely frowned upon. Additionally, I believe alcohol has a more pronounced effect on motor skills, but marijuana can significantly impact one’s lifestyle. Each person reacts differently to substances, and some people tend to moderate their use while others do not. Therefore, it’s challenging to make generalizations about the effects of substances. However, I do believe that both alcohol and marijuana have their own adverse effects.

I think that same-sex marriage should be legalized because there is no good reason not to. Many people believe that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but these couples are different; they have so many diverse aspects that they cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin – heads and tails are not the same, but they are similar. In addition, there are several civil rights that come with marriage, such as property taxes and healthcare, where your partner cannot be with you when you're sick or cannot visit because they're not considered family. This seems silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. They're just relationships, the same thing. People often get hung up on the idea that homosexuals are asking for the right to marry in a church, but they're asking for a legal marriage certificate, a document provided by the government. If there's no church involvement, then it shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why some people, like Catholics, would say it's against their religion or morally wrong, especially when they're not being forced to participate in a church ceremony. If you allow someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the relationship roles played by different partners. People also worry about adoption issues and how gay couples living in their community will affect it, and about the children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society. However, I think the main issue is how children are treated by their peers and adults in society. In New York City, for example, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they often get bullied in public schools. I believe the federal government should make gay marriage legal in every state and that the amendment should be changed to allow it. President Bush has strong views on this issue, primarily based on his religious beliefs. His stance on this issue is similar to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard for opposition are moral reasons, and morality differs from person to person. It's unethical to embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. To create a law banning gay marriage based on the beliefs of religious groups is hypocritical, considering recent controversies like the "under God" pledge and the opposition to it. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe it's due to psychological damage from childhood trauma or personality defects. This is not accurate, according to the American Psychological Association. If people listened to institutions that research these topics instead of popular opinion, the world might be seen differently.

First off, I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and let me tell you, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has beneficial properties. I mean, if we were to make it available to the public, I'd say no, absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I'd say yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial at all. You get what I mean?

Yeah, I mean, there are plenty of drugs that are illegal that pharmacies use, like oxycotton, Vicodin, Percocets, stuff like that. Those are controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. If you deny those benefits just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then there's no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don't think it's that similar to alcohol. If you abuse it, then sure, alcohol can lead to bad things. But marijuana is a tough one. I'd say, not to legalize it all at once, but gradually, because then it might get abused. But if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly. People have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug, but it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. If we get rid of that image of marijuana as this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I believe that everyone was still reeling from the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. There were pretexts that led us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which has since proven false. This has always rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war has always gotten under my skin.

It just seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, who came back from his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn’t convinced by the evidence at the time. And to me, that’s just negligence in office; it’s an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has shown a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since September 11th. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

The last part, I forget the name of the secretary of the treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office. But it seems like the younger Bush kind of came in with a blood vengeance feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his dad’s administration, and I think in the long term, he was hoping to expand our energy supply, which is a very underhanded way to do things.

Well, I do think it’s gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though, because there’s a good chance the country would lapse into civil war, and even more people would die as a result. I think the alternative the UN and the United States are moving to at this point is a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, to come in and try to restore order. But I don’t necessarily know that’s a good idea either, because I think in the long term, that will also cause more problems because Iraq’s sovereignty will become a major issue. It’s pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point.

Just from the news reports I’ve seen, it doesn’t seem that the Parliament is very effective at all. Oh, I can’t remember his name, but the Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what’s happening. Even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and we’re still dealing with fractious radical elements vying for control of the government. And I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

I feel like the war has gone on much longer than necessary. Initially, the purpose was clear: to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal and are now engaged in the conflict merely to demonstrate our power. It seems that the original motivations, including George Bush's father's past disagreements with Saddam Hussein, were questionable. If the aim was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would have been a justifiable cause. However, I do not believe personal matters were involved. I think our purpose was clear at the outset, but the war has dragged on far too long. The conflict has become a means in itself, and we are reluctant to end it without a decisive victory. It has gone on long enough, and it should stop. The Iraqi government will eventually have to stand on its own, and I believe that time has come. We are draining our own economy by spending billions on a war that has long lost its justification. While we struggle with issues like poverty and lack of infrastructure at home, we continue to pour resources into a war that should not be a long-term priority. Instead, we should be investing in our own citizens, improving our public roads, and ensuring access to healthcare.

I feel that there is still a problem with gender discrimination in the United States. It doesn't just affect women; it also depends on the specific field of work you're in. Overall, I think women have it harder because of the glass ceiling, where even if there is supposed to be equality, it's hard for many to work underneath a woman if they're a man, due to societal norms that have existed for so long. In the workplace, women often see jobs they can reach and have the qualifications for, but sometimes the board might not choose to promote them just because historically it hasn't been seen that women are usually in the upper echelons of the business world. The same goes for men, especially in fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. It's really uncommon to have a male parent staying at home, and often people look down on that because society thinks that men should be working and earning money for the family. It can be hard on men who have always dreamed of being with the children and helping to raise them, especially if the wife has a better job. In the fashion industry, people often don't take men seriously if they're straight because they have different lifestyles and people might question if they truly understand fashion for women. Depending on the field of work, there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. Changing it is difficult because society has a set mindset, and while we've come a long way from the 1800s, change is very slow. However, it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. It's also becoming more acceptable for men to be stay-at-home dads, as they realize that the woman might have the better job or wants to be the one working. In the fashion industry, people might think that men are listening to their female friends or wives and understand what they're talking about. So, you kind of have to promote the good qualities of those who are stereotypically against them, not by being too pushy, but by emphasizing their qualities. If you force it, people will resist, and we're already at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced. I don't think there's anything we can do right now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, people will resist. We've come a long way, and change takes time.

My understanding is that they didn’t legalize it; instead, they decriminalized it. This change knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more akin to a traffic violation. You know, something you get cited for rather than being booked and arrested and brought in. And if someone gets caught and cited, those consequences are usually less severe than a drug charge. For example, a marijuana charge can still have future implications, like when it comes to job interviews. While decriminalization doesn’t completely erase these worries, it can also be argued that it saves money on arrests, court appearances, and legal fees. Financial strain can sometimes lead municipalities to be unwilling to make such changes, especially in places where marijuana is widely opposed. However, in more open-minded communities like Denver, it’s generally accepted, and the municipality can then reallocate funds to education, social programs, and services for the elderly and homeless. I don’t think marijuana should be legal and easily accessible everywhere, as it could lead to excessive use and driving under the influence, which is still widely frowned upon. Additionally, I believe alcohol has a more pronounced effect on motor skills, but marijuana can significantly impact one’s lifestyle. Each person reacts differently to substances, and some people tend to moderate their use while others do not. Therefore, it’s challenging to make generalizations about the effects of substances. However, I do believe that both alcohol and marijuana have their own adverse effects.

I think that same-sex marriage should be legalized because there is no good reason not to. Many people believe that homosexual couples pose a threat to traditional families, but these couples are different; they have so many diverse aspects that they cannot be considered the same. It's like two sides of the same coin – heads and tails are not the same, but they are similar. In addition, there are several civil rights that come with marriage, such as property taxes and healthcare, where your partner cannot be with you when you're sick or cannot visit because they're not considered family. This seems silly if you're going to spend the rest of your life with someone. Many scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have the same success rates and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. They're just relationships, the same thing. People often get hung up on the idea that homosexuals are asking for the right to marry in a church, but they're asking for a legal marriage certificate, a document provided by the government. If there's no church involvement, then it shouldn't be an issue. I can't understand why some people, like Catholics, would say it's against their religion or morally wrong, especially when they're not being forced to participate in a church ceremony. If you allow someone a civil union, why not allow them a marriage? It's like segregation – separate but unequal. They are the same in many ways, like the relationship roles played by different partners. People also worry about adoption issues and how gay couples living in their community will affect it, and about the children of gay couples and how they'll adjust to society. However, I think the main issue is how children are treated by their peers and adults in society. In New York City, for example, there are special schools for children of gay parents because they often get bullied in public schools. I believe the federal government should make gay marriage legal in every state and that the amendment should be changed to allow it. President Bush has strong views on this issue, primarily based on his religious beliefs. His stance on this issue is similar to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the reasons I've heard for opposition are moral reasons, and morality differs from person to person. It's unethical to embrace the morality of one group while ignoring the rest. To create a law banning gay marriage based on the beliefs of religious groups is hypocritical, considering recent controversies like the "under God" pledge and the opposition to it. Many people are against gay marriage because they believe it's due to psychological damage from childhood trauma or personality defects. This is not accurate, according to the American Psychological Association. If people listened to institutions that research these topics instead of popular opinion, the world might be seen differently.

First off, I work at a hospital pharmacy during the summer, and let me tell you, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has beneficial properties. I mean, if we were to make it available to the public, I'd say no, absolutely no. But for medicinal purposes, I'd say yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial at all. You get what I mean?

Yeah, I mean, there are plenty of drugs that are illegal that pharmacies use, like oxycotton, Vicodin, Percocets, stuff like that. Those are controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. If you deny those benefits just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then there's no point in doing that for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don't think it's that similar to alcohol. If you abuse it, then sure, alcohol can lead to bad things. But marijuana is a tough one. I'd say, not to legalize it all at once, but gradually, because then it might get abused. But if you just remove that taboo around marijuana first, then people might use it responsibly. People have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug, but it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroin or cocaine or something like that. If we get rid of that image of marijuana as this horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

Initially, I was okay with the premise, but I believe that everyone was still reeling from the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. There were pretexts that led us into Iraq. Early on, the Bush administration connected the Iraq war with Osama Bin Laden and the September 11th attacks, and asserted that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which has since proven false. This has always rubbed me the wrong way, and the Iraq war has always gotten under my skin.

It just seems to me that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility for it. Even Colin Powell, who came back from his big presentation at the UN, now says he wasn’t convinced by the evidence at the time. And to me, that’s just negligence in office; it’s an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that. I think the Bush administration has shown a complete disregard for the constitution and has been trying to marginalize it ever since September 11th. I think they came into office with the intent to go to war.

The last part, I forget the name of the secretary of the treasury who essentially made that allegation in his book after he was probably forced out of his office. But it seems like the younger Bush kind of came in with a blood vengeance feeling against Saddam Hussein because of his dad’s administration, and I think in the long term, he was hoping to expand our energy supply, which is a very underhanded way to do things.

Well, I do think it’s gone on long enough. I think there would be problems if we withdrew right now, though, because there’s a good chance the country would lapse into civil war, and even more people would die as a result. I think the alternative the UN and the United States are moving to at this point is a coalition of nations from the surrounding area, like Syria and Saudi Arabia, to come in and try to restore order. But I don’t necessarily know that’s a good idea either, because I think in the long term, that will also cause more problems because Iraq’s sovereignty will become a major issue. It’s pretty clear that the interim government is dissolving at this point.

Just from the news reports I’ve seen, it doesn’t seem that the Parliament is very effective at all. Oh, I can’t remember his name, but the Prime Minister really has no control over the political process or what’s happening. Even Muqtada al-Sadr, the guy we were fighting less than a year ago, his party now holds at least 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, and we’re still dealing with fractious radical elements vying for control of the government. And I think the political process is experiencing a lot of friction because of that.

I feel like the war has gone on much longer than necessary. Initially, the purpose was clear: to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we have since lost sight of that goal and are now engaged in the conflict merely to demonstrate our power. It seems that the original motivations, including George Bush's father's past disagreements with Saddam Hussein, were questionable. If the aim was to bring democracy to a country without a fair political system, that would have been a justifiable cause. However, I do not believe personal matters were involved. I think our purpose was clear at the outset, but the war has dragged on far too long. The conflict has become a means in itself, and we are reluctant to end it without a decisive victory. It has gone on long enough, and it should stop. The Iraqi government will eventually have to stand on its own, and I believe that time has come. We are draining our own economy by spending billions on a war that has long lost its justification. While we struggle with issues like poverty and lack of infrastructure at home, we continue to pour resources into a war that should not be a long-term priority. Instead, we should be investing in our own citizens, improving our public roads, and ensuring access to healthcare.

I feel that there is still a problem with gender discrimination in the United States. It doesn't just affect women; it also depends on the specific field of work you're in. Overall, I think women have it harder because of the glass ceiling, where even if there is supposed to be equality, it's hard for many to work underneath a woman if they're a man, due to societal norms that have existed for so long. In the workplace, women often see jobs they can reach and have the qualifications for, but sometimes the board might not choose to promote them just because historically it hasn't been seen that women are usually in the upper echelons of the business world. The same goes for men, especially in fields like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent. It's really uncommon to have a male parent staying at home, and often people look down on that because society thinks that men should be working and earning money for the family. It can be hard on men who have always dreamed of being with the children and helping to raise them, especially if the wife has a better job. In the fashion industry, people often don't take men seriously if they're straight because they have different lifestyles and people might question if they truly understand fashion for women. Depending on the field of work, there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. Changing it is difficult because society has a set mindset, and while we've come a long way from the 1800s, change is very slow. However, it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. It's also becoming more acceptable for men to be stay-at-home dads, as they realize that the woman might have the better job or wants to be the one working. In the fashion industry, people might think that men are listening to their female friends or wives and understand what they're talking about. So, you kind of have to promote the good qualities of those who are stereotypically against them, not by being too pushy, but by emphasizing their qualities. If you force it, people will resist, and we're already at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced. I don't think there's anything we can do right now that isn't already being done, because if you do it too fast, people will resist. We've come a long way, and change takes time.

My understanding is that they didn’t legalize it; instead, they decriminalized it. This change knocked it down from a criminal offense to something more akin to a traffic violation. You know, something you get cited for rather than being booked and arrested and brought in. And if someone gets caught and cited, those consequences are usually less severe than a drug charge. For example, a marijuana charge can still have future implications, like when it comes to job interviews. While decriminalization doesn’t completely erase these worries, it can also be argued that it saves money on arrests, court appearances, and legal fees. Financial strain can sometimes lead municipalities to be unwilling to make such changes, especially in places where marijuana is widely opposed. However, in more open-minded communities like Denver, it’s generally accepted, and the municipality can then reallocate funds to education, social programs, and services for the elderly and homeless. I don’t think marijuana should be legal and easily accessible everywhere, as it could lead to excessive use and driving under the influence, which is still widely frowned upon. Additionally, I believe alcohol has a more pronounced effect on motor skills, but marijuana can significantly impact one’s lifestyle. Each person reacts differently to substances, and some people tend to moderate their use while others do not. Therefore, it’s challenging to make generalizations about the effects of substances. However, I do believe that both alcohol and marijuana have their own adverse effects.
